Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.ECM.KR.town_KR5}Połack
Settlement.text: {=ECM_KR_F5HlQdgf}Połack sits in the western foothills of Mount Iltan, on the eastern borders of the Sturgian lands. This region has long stood aloof from the power struggles of the other Sturgian principalities. Its people are known as wanderers, traders, horse breeders and fur-trappers. The local aristocracy has occasionally exchanged princesses with the steppe tribes to the east to firm up a truce or a trade pact, and proudly includes the names of several great khans on their list of ancestors.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.ECM.KR.village_KR5_1}Hłubokaje
Settlement.text: {=ECM_Settlements.Settlement.text.village_KR5_1}Hłubokaje.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.ECM.KR.village_KR5_2}Stryžava
Settlement.text: {=ECM_Settlements.Settlement.text.village_KR5_2}Stryžava

Settlement.name: {=castle_village_KR2_1_ee.name}Słučsk
Settlement.text: {=castle_village_KR2_1_ee.text}Słučsk

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.ECM.KR.castle_village_KR2_2}Babruśk
Settlement.text: {=ECM_Settlements.Settlement.text.village_KR1_2}Babruśk

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.ECM.KR.town_KR4}Riga
Settlement.text: {=ECM_KR_aTMypBiY}Riga, which sits beneath the Chertyg mountains on the crystal waters of Lake Laconis, has the dubious honor of being perhaps the most-often conquered city in Calradia. Originally it was a colony of the Empire, infamous as a place of exile for dissident senators, before it was seized by Nords as a base to expand their influence into the Sturgian fur trade. It was taken by the Alkit tribe from the eastern steppe and briefly served as the capital of a small khanate, before finally falling to the fierce Ormidoving clan.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.ECM.KR.village_KR4_3}Rubeni
Settlement.text: {=ECM_Settlements.Settlement.text.village_KR4_3}Rubeni text.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.ECM.KR.village_KR4_4}Šėta
Settlement.text: {=ECM_Settlements.Settlement.text.village_KR4_4}Šėta.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.ECM.KR.castle_village_KR4_1}Pažeimenė
Settlement.text: {=ECM_Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_KR4_1}Pažeimenė sits in a broaded forested valley looking down on the Galcha river. The villagers in these parts are expert trappers, hunting marten, fox and rabbit for the rich pelts much in demand in the south.

Settlement.name: {=castle_village_KR4_2_ee.name}Usłonim
Settlement.text: {=castle_village_KR4_2_ee.text}Usłonim

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.ECM.village_K4_2}Łomża
Settlement.text: {=ECM_Settlements.Settlement.text.village_K4_2}Ransam in the southeastern plains of the Devseg plateau. Villagers, who not long ago still lived a nomadic lifestyle, specialize in the rearing of horses.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.ECM.castle_village_K4_2}Cathow
Settlement.text: {=ECM_Settlements.Settlement.text.village_K1_3}Kuruluk sits alongside the Zakhan, a tributary of the Karakaz river. Though this valley is snowbound for much of the year, steppe ponies thrive on the spring grasses and in the winter dig through the snow for food, their thick coats protecting them from the icy blasts of wind.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.ECM.KR.town_KR2}Bieraście
Settlement.text: {=ECM_KR_Xom9DeXZ}Volodymyr, which sits on the icy waters of Mazopor bay, was founded by migrants from the Nordlands. Legend holds that the initial wave of Nords arrogantly demanded tribute from the nearby Vakken and Sturgian tribes, who formed an alliance and drove the newcomers back to their ships. But the victors fell out over the spoils, until a canny Nord, Gundar, landed and volunteered to help them fairly divvy up the weapons and armor of his dead kinsmen. The residents recognized Gundar's lordship over the region and his descendants, intermarried with the Sturgians, are today the grand princes of Sturgia.

Settlement.name: {village_KR2_1_ee.name}Svisłoč
Settlement.text: {=village_KR2_1_ee.text}Svisłoč

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.ECM.KR.town_KR3}Halych
Settlement.text: {=ECM_KR_pbHXtJ82}Halych sits on the eastern shores of Lake Laconis. Long before the Sturgians formed themselves into a principality it was a holy site for the forest tribes, who worshipped their gods and ancestors in the sacred oak trees of the nearby woods. Today, it is an emporium for fur trappers and woodsmen who prowl the Ircara wildlands to the east, and the primeval peace of the forests is drowned out by the sounds of bartering, saws, and the unloading of ships at the lake.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.ECM.town_K4}Pułtusk
Settlement.text: {=ECM_Dxnj5JQE}Pułtusk

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.ECM.KR.castle_village_KR6_2}Trikāta
Settlement.text: {=ECM_Settlements.Settlement.text.village_KR2_3}Trikāta.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.ECM.castle_village_K4_1}Krzeszów
Settlement.text: {=ECM_Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_K4_1}Krzeszów

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.ECM.castle_village_EN1_1}Drzeń
Settlement.text: {=ECM_Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_EN1_1}Drzeń

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.ECM.castle_village_EN1_2}Chełmno
Settlement.text: {=ECM_Settlements.Settlement.text.village_EN3_2}Chełmno

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.ECM.town_EN1}Gdańsk
Settlement.text: {=ECM_n9WMUuSp}The first written record thought to refer to Gdańsk is the vita of Saint Adalbert. Written in 999, it describes how in 997 Saint Adalbert of Prague baptised the inhabitants of urbs Gyddannyzc, which separated the great realm of the duke from the sea. No further written sources exist for the 10th and 11th centuries

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.ECM.village_EN1_1}Nakło
Settlement.text: {=ECM_Settlements.Settlement.text.village_EN1_1}Nakło

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.ECM.village_EN1_2}Kołobrzeg
Settlement.text: {=ECM_Settlements.Settlement.text.village_EN1_2}The town's history dates back to a fishermen's settlement from the 10th and 11th centuries. The region became part of Poland soon after the creation of the state in the 10th century. As a result of the 12th-century fragmentation of Poland, it became part of the separate Duchy of Pomerania.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.ECM.village_EN1_3}Słupsk
Settlement.text: {=ECM_Settlements.Settlement.text.village_EN1_3}Since the mid-12th century the Land of Słupsk-Sławno was under the rule of Duke Ratibor I of Pomerania and his descendants, a cadet branch of the Griffin dynasty. From 1190 to 1238 it was the capital of the Duchy of Pomerania-Schlawe.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.ECM.town_K3}Wrocław
Settlement.text: {=ECM_bPDqyqkb}Wroclaw sits on the northern tip of Lake Tanaesis, Tanaz in the steppe tongue. Here, it guards the cataract over which the Karakaz river empties into the lake. This city has long been ruled by petty khans and shahs, who collect tolls from traders forced to haul their boats around the rapids. The last of those rulers was beheaded by Urkhun himself after he refused a demand of tribute, after which the ruling family of the Khuzaits seized this town for themselves.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.ECM.village_K3_1}Głogów
Settlement.text: {=ECM_Settlements.Settlement.text.village_K3_1}Głogów

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.ECM.castle_village_K3_1}Racibórz
Settlement.text: {=ECM_Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_K3_1}Racibórz

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.ECM.town_K6}Kraków
Settlement.text: {=ECM_ygJkPxyc}The town of Kraków sits at the foot of Kohi Rohini, the mountains of the dawn. Among the most remote of the towns of the Devseg, it is reputed to have been the abode of King Ahhak, a mythical tyrant from whose shoulders flowed serpents. Even today the Kohi Rohini has a reputation for black magic and mystery that helps keep outsiders at bay. The city fell during the Khuzait conquest to the Harfit clan, who have intermarried with the mountain peoples, and who honor their customs, participate in their rituals, and keep their secrets.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.ECM.town_K5}Zagreb
Settlement.text: {=ECM_SUnaVliN}Zagreb sits by the reed-marshes on the edge of Lake Tanaesis. In the years when the east was an imperial protectorate, boats laden with hides, wool and salt shuttled across the lake's placid waters, returning with imperial silks and silver. With the coming of the Khuzaits and the subsequent wars the water-trade stopped, but Zagreb remains a major trade entrepot and military base, the fief of the ruling Urkhunait clan. From the pavilions of his palace, the khan can look out across the lake and see the hazy outline of hills that he may one day graze his horses upon.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.ECM.village_K5_2}Szombathely
Settlement.text: {=ECM_Settlements.Settlement.text.village_K5_2}Okhutan is a village at the center of a wheat-growing district on a narrow stretch of plain between the Akkan hills and Lake Tanaesis, which the Khuzaits call the Tanaz Sea.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.ECM.village_K5_3}Buda
Settlement.text: {=ECM_Settlements.Settlement.text.village_K5_3}Ispantar is a village on a rocky spur of the Akkan hills overlooking Lake Tanaesis, which the Khuzaits call the Tanaz Sea. The villagers here make most of their income from the raising of sheep.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.ECM.village_K5_4}Pécs
Settlement.text: {=ECM_Settlements.Settlement.text.village_K5_4}Pabastan sits in the narrow plain between the Akkan hills and Lake Tanaesis, which the Khuzaits call the Tanaz Sea. This land is fine country for wheat.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.ECM.Golden_town_K2}Elets
Settlement.text: {=4UNOQQRa}The town that the Khuzaits know as Akkalat, the White Fortress, was built by the fearsome Padishah Hoshtar on one of his periodic attempts to conquer the Devseg. For decades the sacred flame that burned from the top of the citadel symbolized his suzerainty over the tribes here. But the Padishah's realm like the Empire is on the defensive and has retreated to the east. Today the Khan's horsetail banners fly in its place.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.ECM.Golden_village_K2_1}Ostrogojsk
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_K2_1}Karakalat lies in a basin in the flat, eastern edges of the Devseg plateau. Until recently, this land was dominated by nomads, and it is still famous as a breeding ground for horses.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.ECM.Golden_village_K2_2}Lipetsk
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_K2_2}Tismil sits on the Ozu river, which drains the southern end of the Devseg plateau. The people of this land are sheep-herders, who have thrived under Khuzait overlordship as the khans keep nomadic raiders at bay.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.ECM.KR.castle_village_KR8_2}Rostov Veliki
Settlement.text: {=ECM_Settlements.Settlement.text.village_KR4_2}Rostov Veliki.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.ECM.KR.town_KR6}Novgorod
Settlement.text: {=ECM_KR_PPadNxa6}Novgorod was founded in a dark valley amid the Chertyg mountains by Nordic traders, who wished a base to buy furs from the local Vakken-speaking foresters. As the Sturgian tribes became principalities, and elected chieftains evolved into boyars who demanded taxes and labor as their due, this region became a magnet for Sturgians who had little taste for deference. Today, the ambitious Isyaroving family governs this region, but they must always balance their hunger for wealth and men to fight their wars with their subjects' reluctance to provide it.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.ECM.KR.village_KR6_1}Valdaï
Settlement.text: {=ECM_Settlements.Settlement.text.village_KR6_1}Valdaï.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.ECM.KR.town_KR7}Beloozero
Settlement.text: {=ECM_KR_T2E4xKVn}Tcherepovets, chief town of the rocky Kachyar peninsula, was a traditional rival of Oslo. According to legend the Osloian princess Arkina, whose husband had been slain by the Københavnians, accepted a proposal from her enemy's king to marry and settle the feud. On her wedding night, however, she barred the door of his hall and burned him and a hundred of his kinsmen and warriors alive inside. The feud has long since been settled by pacts and marriages with happier outcomes, although Københavnians still resent the ascent of the Osloian Gundaroving dynasty.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.ECM.castle_village_K8_1}Kolozsvár
Settlement.text: {=ECM_Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_K8_1}Erzenur alongside the Tiagys river, known in the local dialect as the Teyagh. The waters here have a distinct reddish tint from the iron in the soil, which the villagers mine from riverside outcrops.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.ECM.castle_village_K6_1}Napoca
Settlement.text: {=ECM_Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_K6_1}Dinar lies in the far north of the Khuzait confederacy, along the Karakaz river. Snow-bound for much of the year, the spring grasses nonetheless sustain sizeable herds of sheep, the thick wool of which protects them from this land's icy winds.
